Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial of Computer-Assisted Versus Conventional Total Knee Arthroplasty

Trial_Design.evidence: Randomisation was performed at the knee level

Participants.evidence: Eligibility criteria included patients scheduled for bilateral TKA, conducted in a hospital setting.

Intervention.evidence: One knee was operated on using computer navigation, and the other without.

Objective.evidence: This study investigates whether computer-assisted total knee arthroplasty (TKA) offers improved clinical outcomes, radiographic alignment, and component survival compared to conventional TKA.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the Knee Society knee score, assessed at a mean follow-up of 15 years.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed at the knee level, with allocation concealment.

Blinding.evidence: Both patients and assessors were blinded to treatment assignment.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A randomised trial was conducted from October 2000 to October 2002, involving 296 patients undergoing same-day bilateral TKA.

Number_Analysed.evidence: A total of 282 patients (95%) were analysed using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: No significant differences were observed between the computer-assisted and conventional TKA groups in Knee Society knee scores (92 ± 8 vs. 93 ± 7; p = 0.461)

Harms.evidence: Anterior femoral notching was noted in 11 knees (4%) in the computer-assisted group and none in the conventional group (p = 0.046).
